canonical_explanation.text: India was under British rule for nearly 200 years. The British East India Company came to India for trade in the 1600s but gradually took control of the country. The first major revolt against British rule was the Revolt of 1857 (also called the First War of Independence), led by brave fighters like Rani Laxmi Bai of Jhansi and Mangal Pandey. Many great leaders fought for India's freedom. Mahatma Gandhi, called the Father of the Nation, believed in non-violence (ahimsa) and led movements like the Dandi March (Salt March, 1930) and the Quit India Movement (1942) with the slogan 'Do or Die'. Jawaharlal Nehru became India's first Prime Minister and was lovingly called Chacha Nehru by children. Subhash Chandra Bose (Netaji) formed the Indian National Army (INA) and gave the famous call 'Give me blood, I will give you freedom'. Bhagat Singh was a young revolutionary who sacrificed his life for freedom at the age of 23. India finally gained independence on 15 August 1947, and the tricolour was hoisted at the Red Fort in Delhi. The Indian Constitution came into effect on 26 January 1950, which we celebrate as Republic Day.
rules: British East India Company came for trade and gradually took over India
Revolt of 1857: first major uprising, Rani Laxmi Bai, Mangal Pandey
Mahatma Gandhi: Father of the Nation, non-violence (ahimsa), satyagraha
Dandi March (Salt March) 1930: Gandhi walked 385 km to make salt and break the salt law
Quit India Movement 1942: Gandhiji's call 'Do or Die' to the British to leave India
Jawaharlal Nehru: first Prime Minister, Children's Day on 14 November (his birthday)
Subhash Chandra Bose (Netaji): INA, 'Give me blood, I will give you freedom'
Bhagat Singh: young revolutionary, sacrificed his life at age 23
Independence Day: 15 August 1947, tricolour hoisted at Red Fort
Republic Day: 26 January 1950, Constitution of India came into effect

questions.question_text: Why did the British East India Company first come to India?

options.text: For trade in spices, silk, and other goods

questions.explanation_correct: The British East India Company first came to India in the early 1600s for trade. India was known for its spices, silk, cotton, and other valuable goods. Gradually, the Company gained political power and started ruling parts of India.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The British East India Company originally came to India for trade, not to rule. India's spices, silk, and cotton were very valuable in Europe. However, over time, the Company gained political and military power and began controlling Indian territories.

questions.question_text: For approximately how many years was India under British rule?
questions.explanation_correct: India was under British control for nearly 200 years. The British East India Company established significant control by the mid-1700s, and the British Crown took direct control after 1858. India gained independence in 1947.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The British ruled India for nearly 200 years. Starting from the mid-1700s when the East India Company gained major control, through to 1947 when India gained independence, the British dominated Indian politics and economy.

questions.question_text: The Revolt of 1857 is also known as:

options.text: The First War of Indian Independence

questions.explanation_correct: The Revolt of 1857 is also called the First War of Indian Independence. It was the first large-scale uprising against British rule. Indian soldiers (sepoys) along with kings and queens like Rani Laxmi Bai fought against the British.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Revolt of 1857 is called the First War of Indian Independence. It was different from the Quit India Movement (1942), the Salt March (1930), and the Non-Cooperation Movement (1920-22), which all came much later.

questions.question_text: The British East India Company came to India only to rule the country.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. The British East India Company originally came to India for trade, especially in spices and textiles. They gradually gained political and military power and eventually started ruling parts of India.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This statement is false. The Company came for trade, not to rule. However, over time, they took advantage of political divisions among Indian rulers and slowly established their control over the country.

questions.question_text: The British took advantage of which factor to gain control over India?

options.text: Indians were too strong and united
Divisions and rivalries among Indian kings and rulers
Indian people invited them to rule

questions.explanation_correct: The British took advantage of divisions and rivalries among Indian rulers. Different kings and kingdoms were fighting with each other, and the British played them against one another, gradually gaining control over more and more territory.
questions.explanation_incorrect: India was rich in resources, but the rivalry between Indian kings allowed the British to use a 'divide and rule' strategy. They supported one ruler against another and slowly expanded their own control over Indian territories.

questions.question_text: Which brave queen fought against the British during the Revolt of 1857?
questions.explanation_correct: Rani Laxmi Bai of Jhansi was one of the bravest leaders of the Revolt of 1857. When the British tried to take over her kingdom of Jhansi, she fought back fiercely. She is remembered as a symbol of courage and patriotism.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rani Laxmi Bai of Jhansi was the brave queen who fought the British in 1857. She refused to give up her kingdom and led her army into battle. Her courage inspired many Indians to fight for their freedom.

questions.question_text: Who is known as the 'Father of the Nation'?
questions.explanation_correct: Mahatma Gandhi is known as the Father of the Nation. His full name was Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi. He led the Indian freedom movement using non-violence (ahimsa) and truth (satyagraha) as his main weapons against British rule.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mahatma Gandhi is called the Father of the Nation for his leading role in the Indian independence movement. He believed in non-violence and peaceful protest. His methods inspired millions of Indians to join the freedom struggle.

questions.question_text: What method did Mahatma Gandhi use to fight for India's freedom?

options.text: Asking other countries for help only

questions.explanation_correct: Mahatma Gandhi used non-violence (ahimsa) and satyagraha (the force of truth) as his main methods to fight British rule. He believed that peaceful protests, fasting, and civil disobedience were more powerful than violence.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Gandhi firmly believed in non-violence (ahimsa) and satyagraha. He never used weapons or war. Instead, he used peaceful methods like marches, fasting, boycotts, and non-cooperation to oppose British rule.

questions.question_text: Who was the first Prime Minister of independent India?
questions.explanation_correct: Jawaharlal Nehru was the first Prime Minister of independent India. He served from 1947 until his death in 1964. He was lovingly called 'Chacha Nehru' by children, and his birthday (14 November) is celebrated as Children's Day.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Jawaharlal Nehru was India's first Prime Minister. He delivered the famous 'Tryst with Destiny' speech on the night of 14 August 1947. Mahatma Gandhi was the Father of the Nation but not the Prime Minister.

questions.question_text: Children's Day is celebrated on 14 November because it is the birthday of:
questions.explanation_correct: Children's Day is celebrated on 14 November, the birthday of Jawaharlal Nehru. He was lovingly called 'Chacha Nehru' (Uncle Nehru) because of his great love for children. Schools celebrate this day with fun activities and events.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 14 November is the birthday of Jawaharlal Nehru, who loved children dearly and was called Chacha Nehru. Gandhi's birthday (2 October) is celebrated as Gandhi Jayanti. Bose's birthday (23 January) is celebrated as Parakram Diwas.

questions.question_text: Subhash Chandra Bose was also known as:
questions.explanation_correct: Subhash Chandra Bose was lovingly called 'Netaji', meaning 'Respected Leader'. He formed the Indian National Army (INA) and gave the famous slogan 'Give me blood, I will give you freedom'. His birthday (23 January) is celebrated as Parakram Diwas.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Subhash Chandra Bose was called 'Netaji'. 'Mahatma' (great soul) was for Gandhi, 'Chacha' (uncle) for Nehru, and 'Sardar' (chief) for Vallabhbhai Patel. Netaji formed the INA to fight the British with an army.

questions.question_text: Which famous slogan was given by Subhash Chandra Bose?

options.text: Give me blood, I will give you freedom

questions.explanation_correct: 'Give me blood, I will give you freedom' was the famous call given by Subhash Chandra Bose to inspire Indians to join the Indian National Army (INA) and fight for India's independence from British rule.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 'Give me blood, I will give you freedom' was Netaji Subhash Chandra Bose's famous slogan. 'Do or Die' was Gandhi's call during the Quit India Movement. 'Inquilab Zindabad' (Long live the revolution) was popularised by Bhagat Singh.

questions.question_text: Bhagat Singh was a young revolutionary who sacrificed his life for India's freedom at the age of:
questions.explanation_correct: Bhagat Singh was hanged by the British on 23 March 1931, when he was just 23 years old. Along with Rajguru and Sukhdev, he sacrificed his life for India's freedom. He is remembered as one of the bravest freedom fighters.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bhagat Singh was only 23 years old when he was executed by the British on 23 March 1931. Despite his young age, his courage and sacrifice inspired millions of Indians to join the freedom movement.

questions.question_text: Mahatma Gandhi's full name was Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Mahatma Gandhi's full name was Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi. He was born on 2 October 1869 in Porbandar, Gujarat. 'Mahatma' is a title meaning 'great soul' and was given to him by the people of India.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This statement is true. His full name was Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi. 'Mahatma' was not his first name but a title meaning 'great soul', given to him by the people of India for his noble character and leadership.

questions.question_text: Mangal Pandey was an Indian soldier who revolted against the British in 1857. What does this tell us about the freedom struggle?

options.text: The freedom struggle started only in the 1900s
Even ordinary soldiers were brave enough to stand up against the British
Soldiers were not part of the freedom movement

questions.explanation_correct: Mangal Pandey was an ordinary Indian soldier (sepoy) in the British army who refused to follow unjust British orders and revolted. His bravery shows that the freedom struggle involved not just leaders but also ordinary people willing to sacrifice for their country.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mangal Pandey's revolt shows that the struggle for freedom involved all kinds of people, including ordinary soldiers. He was brave enough to stand up against the powerful British army, inspiring others to join the fight.

questions.question_text: Match the freedom fighter with their title: Gandhi = _____, Nehru = _____, Bose = _____.
questions.explanation_correct: Mahatma (great soul) Gandhi, Chacha (uncle) Nehru, and Netaji (respected leader) Bose. Each title reflects how the people of India loved and respected these leaders for their different qualities and contributions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct titles are: Gandhi = Mahatma (great soul), Nehru = Chacha (uncle, because he loved children), Bose = Netaji (respected leader). Sardar was the title given to Vallabhbhai Patel.

questions.question_text: The Dandi March (Salt March) was led by Mahatma Gandhi in which year?
questions.explanation_correct: The Dandi March (Salt March) took place in 1930. Mahatma Gandhi and his followers walked about 385 kilometres from Sabarmati Ashram to Dandi on the Gujarat coast to make salt from seawater, breaking the unjust British salt law.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Dandi March happened in 1930. Gandhi walked 385 km to the coast of Dandi in Gujarat to protest the British salt tax. 1920 was the Non-Cooperation Movement, 1942 was Quit India, and 1947 was Independence.

questions.question_text: Why did Mahatma Gandhi lead the Salt March?

options.text: To protest the British tax on salt, which affected every Indian
To sell salt to the British

questions.explanation_correct: The British had made it illegal for Indians to make their own salt and imposed a heavy tax on it. Since salt was used by everyone, this tax affected every Indian, rich or poor. Gandhi marched to Dandi to make salt from seawater and break this unjust law.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Gandhi marched to Dandi to protest against the unfair British salt tax. Salt was an essential item used by every Indian, so taxing it heavily was cruel. By making salt himself, Gandhi showed that Indians would not accept unjust British laws.

questions.question_text: The Quit India Movement was launched in which year?
questions.explanation_correct: The Quit India Movement was launched on 8 August 1942. Mahatma Gandhi gave the call 'Do or Die' to the Indian people, demanding that the British leave India immediately. It was one of the most significant movements in the freedom struggle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Quit India Movement began in 1942 with Gandhi's famous 'Do or Die' slogan. It demanded that the British leave India immediately. 1930 was the Salt March, and 1947 was when India actually gained independence.

questions.question_text: What was the famous slogan of the Quit India Movement?

options.text: Give me blood, I will give you freedom

questions.explanation_correct: 'Do or Die' was the slogan given by Mahatma Gandhi during the Quit India Movement in 1942. It meant that Indians should either achieve freedom or die trying. This powerful call united millions of Indians against British rule.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 'Do or Die' was Gandhi's call during the Quit India Movement (1942). 'Jai Hind' was popularised by Bose, 'Give me blood...' was Bose's slogan, and 'Swaraj is my birthright' was said by Bal Gangadhar Tilak.

questions.question_text: During the Salt March, Gandhi walked about 385 kilometres from Sabarmati Ashram to Dandi.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Gandhi started the Salt March on 12 March 1930 from Sabarmati Ashram in Ahmedabad and walked about 385 kilometres (240 miles) to Dandi on the coast of Gujarat, reaching there on 6 April 1930.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This statement is true. The Salt March covered about 385 km over 24 days. Gandhi started with 78 followers and thousands joined along the way. At Dandi, he picked up salt from the seashore, breaking the British salt law.

questions.question_text: Gandhi chose salt as a symbol of protest because:

options.text: Salt was very expensive and only rich people used it
Salt was needed by every Indian, rich or poor, so the salt tax affected everyone
Salt was not available in India
He wanted to start a salt business

questions.explanation_correct: Gandhi was brilliant in choosing salt as a symbol of protest. Every Indian, whether rich or poor, needed salt in their daily food. By protesting the salt tax, Gandhi united all Indians against a common injustice that affected everyone equally.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Salt was a basic necessity used by every Indian. The British salt tax was unjust because it forced even the poorest people to pay extra for something essential. Gandhi's genius was choosing an issue that every Indian could relate to.

questions.question_text: The Non-Cooperation Movement asked Indians to:

options.text: Stop cooperating with the British: boycott British goods, schools, and courts

questions.explanation_correct: The Non-Cooperation Movement (1920-22) asked Indians to stop cooperating with the British government. People boycotted British goods, stopped attending British schools and courts, and gave up government jobs. They used Indian-made (swadeshi) goods instead.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Non-Cooperation Movement was about NOT cooperating with the British in any way. Indians boycotted British goods, schools, and courts. They wore khadi (hand-spun cloth) instead of British cloth, supporting the swadeshi (Indian-made) movement.

questions.question_text: Arrange these events in the correct order from earliest to latest:

options.text: Quit India Movement → Salt March → Revolt of 1857
Revolt of 1857 → Salt March → Quit India Movement
Salt March → Revolt of 1857 → Quit India Movement
Revolt of 1857 → Quit India Movement → Salt March

questions.explanation_correct: The correct chronological order is: Revolt of 1857 (first major uprising) → Salt March of 1930 (Gandhi's protest against salt tax) → Quit India Movement of 1942 (Gandhi's call for the British to leave India).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct order is: Revolt of 1857 → Salt March (1930) → Quit India Movement (1942). Remember: 1857 was the first major revolt, 1930 was when Gandhi walked to Dandi, and 1942 was when Gandhi said 'Do or Die'.

questions.question_text: On which date did India gain independence?
questions.explanation_correct: India gained independence from British rule on 15 August 1947. On this day, the Indian tricolour flag was hoisted at the Red Fort in Delhi by Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru. We celebrate this day every year as Independence Day.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 15 August 1947 is India's Independence Day. 26 January 1950 is Republic Day (when the Constitution came into effect). 2 October is Gandhi Jayanti, and 14 November is Children's Day.

questions.question_text: Where is the Indian tricolour hoisted every year on Independence Day?
questions.explanation_correct: Every year on 15 August, the Prime Minister of India hoists the national flag at the Red Fort in Delhi and addresses the nation. This tradition started in 1947 when Jawaharlal Nehru hoisted the tricolour at the Red Fort for the first time.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The tricolour is hoisted at the Red Fort in Delhi on Independence Day by the Prime Minister. On Republic Day (26 January), the flag is unfurled at Rajpath (now Kartavya Path) by the President of India.

questions.question_text: Republic Day is celebrated on:
questions.explanation_correct: Republic Day is celebrated on 26 January every year. On this day in 1950, the Constitution of India came into effect, making India a republic. A grand parade is held at Kartavya Path (formerly Rajpath) in New Delhi.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Republic Day is on 26 January. 15 August is Independence Day, 2 October is Gandhi Jayanti, and 14 November is Children's Day. Republic Day celebrates the adoption of the Indian Constitution on 26 January 1950.

questions.question_text: Why do we celebrate Republic Day on 26 January?

options.text: India gained independence on this day
The Indian Constitution came into effect on this day in 1950
Mahatma Gandhi was born on this day
The Salt March started on this day

questions.explanation_correct: Republic Day is celebrated because the Constitution of India came into effect on 26 January 1950. This made India a sovereign, democratic republic where the people's rights and duties were defined by the Constitution.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 26 January marks the day the Constitution of India came into effect in 1950. Independence was gained on 15 August 1947, Gandhi was born on 2 October, and the Salt March started on 12 March 1930.

questions.question_text: Independence Day and Republic Day are the same thing.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. Independence Day (15 August 1947) celebrates India's freedom from British rule. Republic Day (26 January 1950) celebrates the day the Indian Constitution came into effect. They are two different national celebrations.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This is false. Independence Day and Republic Day are different. Independence Day (15 August) marks freedom from British rule. Republic Day (26 January) marks the day India became a republic with its own Constitution.

questions.question_text: On Republic Day, a grand parade is held in Delhi. Which of the following can you see in this parade?

options.text: Tableaux from different states, military parade, and school children performing

questions.explanation_correct: The Republic Day parade at Kartavya Path includes a military parade, fly-past by the Indian Air Force, tableaux (decorated displays) from different states showing their culture, school children performing dances, and the Beating Retreat ceremony.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Republic Day parade includes many elements: the military displays its strength, different states present beautiful tableaux showing their culture, school children perform, and the President takes the salute. It showcases India's diversity and strength.

questions.question_text: On Independence Day, the flag is _____ by the Prime Minister, while on Republic Day, the flag is _____ by the President.
questions.explanation_correct: On Independence Day, the Prime Minister hoists the flag (pulls it up from the bottom) at the Red Fort. On Republic Day, the President unfurls the flag (it is already at the top and is opened) at Kartavya Path. This difference is significant.
questions.explanation_incorrect: On Independence Day, the flag is hoisted (raised from bottom to top) by the Prime Minister. On Republic Day, the flag is unfurled (opened when already at the top) by the President. This is an important distinction.

questions.question_text: What does 'satyagraha' mean?

options.text: Force of truth; insistence on truth

questions.explanation_correct: Satyagraha means 'force of truth' or 'insistence on truth'. It was Mahatma Gandhi's philosophy of peaceful resistance. He believed that truth and non-violence are the most powerful weapons, stronger than any army.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Satyagraha means 'force of truth' (satya = truth, agraha = insistence). Gandhi used this method of peaceful protest against the British. It was about standing firm for truth and justice without using any violence.

questions.question_text: The Swadeshi Movement encouraged Indians to:

options.text: Use Indian-made goods and boycott foreign products

questions.explanation_correct: The Swadeshi Movement encouraged Indians to use goods made in India (swadeshi = of one's own country). People boycotted British cloth and wore khadi (hand-spun cotton cloth). This supported Indian craftsmen and weakened British trade.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Swadeshi means 'of one's own country'. The movement asked Indians to boycott foreign (especially British) goods and use Indian-made products instead. Gandhi himself spun khadi on a charkha (spinning wheel) to promote this idea.

questions.question_text: Gandhi used a charkha (spinning wheel) to spin cloth. What was the message behind this?

options.text: That spinning is a fun hobby
That Indians should be self-reliant and not depend on British goods
That only Gandhi could spin cloth

questions.explanation_correct: By spinning cloth on a charkha, Gandhi sent a powerful message of self-reliance (swadeshi). He showed that Indians could make their own cloth and did not need to buy expensive British-made fabric. The charkha became a symbol of India's independence movement.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Gandhi's charkha was a symbol of self-reliance and the swadeshi movement. By making his own cloth (khadi), he showed Indians that they could be self-sufficient and need not depend on British factories. This was a peaceful form of protest.

questions.question_text: What can we learn from Bhagat Singh's sacrifice for the country?

options.text: That young people can make a big difference and freedom requires courage and sacrifice
That only old people should fight for freedom

questions.explanation_correct: Bhagat Singh's sacrifice at just 23 years of age teaches us that young people can have a huge impact on society. His courage, love for his country, and willingness to give up his life for freedom inspire us to value our independence and serve our nation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bhagat Singh was only 23 when he sacrificed his life for India. His story teaches us that age does not matter when it comes to serving the nation. Young or old, anyone can contribute to making their country better.

questions.question_text: Ahimsa means violence.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. Ahimsa means NON-violence. 'A' means 'non' and 'himsa' means 'violence'. Mahatma Gandhi firmly believed in ahimsa and used it as a powerful tool to fight against British rule without any weapons.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ahimsa means non-violence, not violence. It was the core principle of Mahatma Gandhi's freedom movement. He proved that peaceful protests could be more powerful than weapons in fighting for justice and freedom.

questions.question_text: Which of the following values did the Indian freedom struggle teach us?

options.text: Non-violence, courage, sacrifice, and love for the country

questions.explanation_correct: The Indian freedom struggle taught us many important values: non-violence (from Gandhi), courage (from Rani Laxmi Bai and Bhagat Singh), sacrifice (from all freedom fighters), self-reliance (from the swadeshi movement), and love for the country.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The freedom struggle was about the exact opposite of selfishness and giving up. Our freedom fighters showed non-violence, incredible courage, willingness to sacrifice their lives, and deep love for their country and its people.

questions.question_text: Gandhi Jayanti is celebrated on 2 October. It is also observed internationally as:
questions.explanation_correct: 2 October, Mahatma Gandhi's birthday, is observed internationally as the International Day of Non-Violence. The United Nations declared this in 2007 to honour Gandhi's philosophy of non-violence and to spread his message of peace worldwide.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Gandhi Jayanti (2 October) is internationally recognised as the International Day of Non-Violence. This recognition by the United Nations shows that Gandhi's philosophy of ahimsa (non-violence) has inspired the entire world.

questions.question_text: Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel is known as the _____ of India for uniting all princely states.
questions.explanation_correct: Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel is called the 'Iron Man of India'. After independence, India had over 500 princely states. Patel united all of them into one India through diplomacy and firm determination. The Statue of Unity in Gujarat honours him.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sardar Patel is the 'Iron Man of India' because of his strong will and determination in uniting over 500 princely states into the Republic of India. The world's tallest statue, the Statue of Unity in Gujarat, was built to honour him.

questions.question_text: Which slogan is correctly matched with its freedom fighter?

options.text: 'Give me blood, I will give you freedom' - Subhash Chandra Bose

questions.explanation_correct: 'Give me blood, I will give you freedom' was the famous slogan of Subhash Chandra Bose (Netaji). 'Inquilab Zindabad' was popularised by Bhagat Singh, 'Do or Die' was Gandhi's call, and 'Swaraj is my birthright' was Bal Gangadhar Tilak's slogan.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct match is 'Give me blood, I will give you freedom' - Subhash Chandra Bose. Other correct matchings: 'Do or Die' - Gandhi, 'Inquilab Zindabad' - Bhagat Singh, 'Swaraj is my birthright' - Tilak.

questions.question_text: What was the impact of British rule on Indian crafts and industries?

options.text: Indian industries flourished under British rule
British policies destroyed Indian handloom and local industries
There was no impact at all

questions.explanation_correct: British policies were harmful to Indian industries. They forced Indians to buy British-made goods and destroyed local handloom weavers and craftsmen. Raw materials from India were taken to Britain, and finished goods were sold back at high prices.
questions.explanation_incorrect: British rule damaged Indian industries significantly. They took raw materials like cotton from India, manufactured cloth in British factories, and sold it back to Indians at high prices. This is why the Swadeshi movement was so important.

questions.question_text: Which of the following freedom fighters formed the Indian National Army (INA)?
questions.explanation_correct: Subhash Chandra Bose (Netaji) formed the Indian National Army (INA), also called the Azad Hind Fauj. Unlike Gandhi's non-violent approach, Bose believed that armed struggle was needed to free India from British rule.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Netaji Subhash Chandra Bose formed the INA (Indian National Army/Azad Hind Fauj). While Gandhi used non-violence, Bose took a different path and raised an army to fight for India's freedom.

questions.question_text: The famous slogan 'Inquilab Zindabad' means _____ and was popularised by _____.
questions.explanation_correct: 'Inquilab Zindabad' means 'Long Live the Revolution' and was popularised by Bhagat Singh. This powerful slogan became a rallying cry for the Indian independence movement, inspiring people to fight against British injustice.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 'Inquilab Zindabad' (Long Live the Revolution) was made famous by Bhagat Singh. It became one of the most popular slogans of the freedom movement. Bhagat Singh shouted this in court while being tried by the British.

questions.question_text: How can we, as students, honour the sacrifices of our freedom fighters?

options.text: By being good citizens, respecting our country, and working hard for India's progress
By wasting the freedom they gave us

questions.explanation_correct: We honour our freedom fighters by being responsible citizens, studying well, respecting our national symbols, following the law, and working to make India a better country. Their sacrifice gave us freedom, and we should use it wisely to build a strong, united India.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Our freedom fighters sacrificed everything so that we could live in a free India. The best way to honour them is to be good citizens: study hard, respect our country, help others, and work for India's progress.

questions.question_text: Rani Laxmi Bai's famous words were 'Main meri Jhansi nahi doongi' meaning 'I will not give up my Jhansi'. What does this tell us about her?

options.text: She was afraid of the British
She was courageous and determined to protect her kingdom
She did not care about Jhansi

questions.explanation_correct: Rani Laxmi Bai's words show her incredible courage and determination. She refused to give up her kingdom of Jhansi to the British and fought bravely on horseback with a sword. She is one of the greatest symbols of bravery in Indian history.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rani Laxmi Bai was the opposite of afraid. Her famous declaration shows her courage and love for her kingdom. She fought the British army on horseback and is remembered as one of the bravest women in Indian history.

questions.question_text: On Republic Day, the President of India unfurls the national flag at Kartavya Path in New Delhi.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. On Republic Day (26 January), the President of India unfurls the national flag at Kartavya Path (formerly Rajpath) in New Delhi. This is followed by a grand parade with military displays, cultural tableaux, and performances.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This statement is true. On Republic Day, the President unfurls the flag at Kartavya Path (formerly Rajpath). On Independence Day, it is the Prime Minister who hoists the flag at the Red Fort.

questions.question_text: What does 'Swadeshi' mean?
questions.explanation_correct: Swadeshi means 'of one's own country'. The Swadeshi Movement encouraged Indians to use goods made in India instead of buying British-made products. By supporting Indian goods, people helped Indian craftsmen and weakened British trade in India.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Swadeshi means 'of one's own country' or 'Indian-made'. The Swadeshi Movement encouraged Indians to buy and use products made in India. This was a powerful economic protest against British control of Indian markets.

questions.question_text: Which pair of freedom fighters represents contrasting approaches to the freedom struggle?

options.text: Gandhi and Nehru (both used the same methods)
Bhagat Singh and Mangal Pandey (both lived at the same time)
Rani Laxmi Bai and Patel (both fought in 1857)

questions.explanation_correct: Gandhi believed in non-violence (ahimsa) and satyagraha, while Bose believed that armed struggle through the INA was needed to free India. Despite their different approaches, both had the same goal: India's independence. Their contrasting methods show different ways to fight for freedom.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Gandhi and Bose represent two different approaches: Gandhi used non-violence while Bose believed in armed struggle. Despite their differences, both were deeply patriotic and dedicated to freeing India from British rule.

questions.question_text: Who led the Revolt of 1857 alongside Rani Laxmi Bai? Select the other important leader.
questions.explanation_correct: Mangal Pandey was an Indian sepoy (soldier) in the British army who revolted against the British, sparking the Revolt of 1857. Along with Rani Laxmi Bai, Tatya Tope, and Bahadur Shah Zafar, he is remembered as a hero of the first war of independence.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mangal Pandey and Rani Laxmi Bai were both leaders of the 1857 revolt. Gandhi, Nehru, and Bose were all born much later and led the freedom struggle in the 1900s. The 1857 revolt was the first major uprising against the British.

questions.question_text: If you could meet one freedom fighter and ask them a question, which question would best show your understanding of the freedom struggle?

options.text: What gave you the courage to sacrifice everything for India's freedom?
Did you have a mobile phone?
What was the weather like in those days?

questions.explanation_correct: Asking about their courage and motivation shows you understand the spirit of the freedom struggle. Freedom fighters like Gandhi, Bhagat Singh, and Rani Laxmi Bai gave up comfort, safety, and even their lives because they believed in India's right to be free. Understanding their motivation helps us appreciate our freedom.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The best question would be about their courage and sacrifice, as that is the heart of the freedom struggle. Understanding what motivated them to fight for India's independence helps us value the freedom we enjoy today.
